items.author: Marjorie Baumgarten
items.content: It's paved with delightfully irregular and unanticipated bits of business that stimulate the viewer to stay fully alert, while renewing our faith in the sheer joy of watching movies.

items.author: Rick Groen
items.content: It's a pinball arcade of a flick -- the Coens invent a bunch of wonderfully flaky characters, stick them into a Plexiglas narrative, and let them bounce off each other.

items.author: Roger Ebert
items.content: Some may complain The Big Lebowski rushes in all directions and never ends up anywhere. That isn't the film's flaw, but its style.

items.author: David Sterritt
items.content: Viewers with a taste for bizarre, even surreal, humor will have a ball.
It's neither the clean strike Coen-heads expected after Fargo nor the gutter ball anticipated by Coen-phobes like myself.

items.author: Jonathan Rosenbaum
items.content: The Big Lebowski is packed with show-offy filmmaking and as a result is pretty entertaining.

items.author: Owen Gleiberman
items.content: Nearly everything in The Big Lebowski is a put-on, but all that leaves you with is the Coens' bizarrely over-deliberate, almost Teutonic form of rib nudging.

items.author: Edward Guthmann
items.content: Although some of its parts are brilliantly executed and played by a terrific cast, the result is scattered, overamplified and unsatisfying.

items.author: Barbara Shulgasser
items.content: It is a visual tour de force, but as a whole the movie slowly deflates into a cross between "Arizona" and "The Hudsucker Proxy".

items.author: Ken Fox
items.content: If it's all supposed to be in fun, why does it feel so much like an insult?
